At-a-glance Embed Article Print Article Share Article Short URL for Sharing [ArticleImageHyperLink] Obesity epidemic sees no end in sight Monday, March 12, 2012 By Maggie Paese Advertising Everyone knows of its dangers and why it is happening, but are we taking it seriously? Have we done enough to reverse the numbers? Studies show that we have not: one in three kids in the United States is affected by the epidemic. The cause is simple; these days, kids spend too much time on the computer and in front of the TV and not enough playing outside. Junk food tastes better than fruit, and McDonalds is an easy, inexpensive and enjoyable meal for busy people. Habits like these can be hard to break and generally carry through into adulthood. Of course, the government has been taking action to stop the increasing numbers. With her Let’s Move! Campaign, first lady Michelle Obama has helped promote healthy foods and physical activity among children by encouraging parents, schools and kids to work together and prevent obesity. The NFL has launched the Play 60 movement to promote daily exercise that kids will enjoy. The U.S. Department of Agriculture has recently updated nutrition standards in schools to ensure that kids are getting healthy meals as well. This shows that the country is aware of the dangers of the epidemic and is working to fix it. However, government programs cannot be the only solution. People hear about these campaigns but may not be affected by them. These are likely not going to be enough to change the habits of citizens throughout the country. Instead, change needs to come from the individuals in this country. It is entirely a personal decision to eat a healthy, home cooked meal instead of picking up a burger or a pizza from a fast food restaurant. No one else will actually dictate when one takes time to exercise. People need the motivation and the desire to keep themselves healthy. It is still important for the government to be taking action in this situation and keeping the public aware of the rising obesity problem, but this is not enough. There is still too much fast food and junk food being consumed on a regular basis. There are too many video games, social networking sites and TV shows that are keeping people on the couch instead of outside or at the gym. Unless we find a way to raise motivation and inspire U.S. citizens to truly change their eating and exercising habits, the obesity epidemic may not reverse any time soon. People do not want to change things in their life that are easy, enjoyable and affordable to things that are more difficult, less enjoyable and more expensive. To bring about this change, they must understand that these changes are crucial and will have a lasting impact on their own lives.
